answers.answer: I agree with the reduced dosage   did the reaction start in the head and work down to the feet?   allergic reactions act that way, neuropathy  is loss of nerve reactions and when the nerves start jangling the pain is terrible.  Stay away from all hot water  and hot foods.  Onocologists do not know enough about pain, its a pity too.   Did they give you benadryl following chemo?Allergic ReactionsAllergic reactions to Neulasta®, including anaphylaxis, skin rash, urticaria, and erythema/flushing have been reported in post marketing experience. The majority of reported events occurred upon initial exposure. In some cases, symptoms recurred with rechallenge, suggesting a causal relationship. In rare cases, allergic reactions including anaphylaxis, recurred within days after initial anti-allergic treatment was discontinued. If a serious allergic reaction occurs, appropriate therapy should be administered, with close patient follow-up over several days. Neulasta® should be permanently discontinued in patients with serious allergic reactions.I would bet it was the Neulasta  that also gave you a reaction if you were already sensitized  by a reaction to the chemo.Decadron side effectsIncreased appetiteIrritabilityDifficulty sleeping (insomnia)Swelling in your ankles and feet (fluid retention)HeartburnMuscle weaknessImpaired wound healingIncreased blood sugar levels. Hi....I was wondering if your feet change color at all??? Like changing from white to blue or bright red? Do they get really cold? Sometimes because of steroids and other things you take.which are vasoconstrictors...it can cause your small blood vessels to constrict. This can cause coldness and numbness and then when the circulation returns it can cause a lot of pain in your feet or even fingers. If this sounds like something you have then you might look into Raynauds. No pain medications really help it only keeping them warm and maintaining good circulation. Victoria

This is a link for Raynauds...under the causes of secondary Raynauds you will see chemotherapy listed as a cause. It will also describe it better so that you are better able to determine if this is a possibility.http://www.apsfa.org/raynauds.htmI have this because of autoimmune problems, but I have met some people who have it because of chemotherapy. That is what made me think of it. Hope this helps....and if not it then maybe someone can give you more answers. Good luck.

question: Hi, well thanks to all your support I went and had my first chemo treatment on Wednesday, December 12, 2007.  I have been diagonosed IC, the cancer was confined to my ovary, but the bodywashings tested positive for cell.  This was my first treatment and I had serious red face and swelling down to my chest and a swollen tongue and throat.  Most of this has gone away except for the swelling in my throat, but my white blood cell was so low they had to give me a neulasta shot Friday morning.  Late Saturday eveening I lost feeling in my feet when trying to stand, the feeling is coming back, but the pain is unbelievable now.  Hydrocodone does nothing for it.  My onc says it is all a reaction to the Decadron, but the ER onc says its is probably neuropathy and my onc needs to reduce my doses.  Does anybody have any thoughts.  I was also wondering if the pain could be from the Neulasta shot.  I don't think I can drive to work the pain is so bad.  Thanks for your support and input.
